page.title: Illegal immigration from Africa to Israel

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} '''Illegal immigration from Africa to Israel''' (often also referred to as '''infiltration''' by the Israeli media<ref>{{cite news |author=Ron Friedman |date=2 February 2010 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Human-rights-groups-slam-state-on-refugee-statements |title=Human rights groups slam state on refugee statements |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Attila Somfalvi |date=13 December 2010 |url=http://www.shebacss.com/en/media-center-59784.html |title=Israel deporting Sudanese infiltrators |newspaper=[[Yedioth Ahronoth]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716052836/http://www.shebacss.com/en/media-center-59784.html |archivedate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Yehuda Bauer |authorlink=Yehuda Bauer |date=28 December 2010 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Op-Ed-Contributors/Why-should-we-care |title=Why should we care? |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=16 September 2014 |quote=Today, the national policy is to stop the infiltration of Africans from Egypt as drastically as possible.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Dana Weiler-Polak |date=22 November 2010 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/eli-yishai-infiltrators-pose-existential-threat-to-israel-1.326075 |title=Eli Yishai: Infiltrators pose existential threat to Israel |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=14 December 2010 |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3998642,00.html |title=Israel flying Sudanese infiltrators back to Africa |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> and by Israeli government organizations;<ref>{{cite web |date=19 July 2010 |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/mfa/pressroom/2010/pages/israel_block_infiltrators_africa_19-jul-2010.aspx |title=Israel to take significant steps to block infiltrators from Africa |publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=19 July 2010 |url=http://www.pmo.gov.il/PMOEng/Communication/Spokesman/2010/07/spokeafrica190710.htm |title=Israel to Take Significant Steps to Block Infiltrators from Africa |publisher=[[Prime Minister of Israel]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726032545/http://www.pmo.gov.il/PMOEng/Communication/Spokesman/2010/07/spokeafrica190710.htm |archivedate=26 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mops.gov.il/BPEng/MOPS+News/MinisterDicterVisitsAfricanRefugees_18_7_07.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805144435/http://www.mops.gov.il/BPEng/MOPS+News/MinisterDicterVisitsAfricanRefugees_18_7_07.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-05 |title=The IDF is responsible for preventing infiltration through the border |publisher=[[Ministry of Public Security (Israel)]]}}</ref> however, the use of the term has been criticized<ref>{{cite news |author=Michael Handelzalts |date=29 June 2012 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/pen-ultimate/word-for-word-by-renaming-migrants-infiltrators-israel-is-forging-a-new-reality.premium-1.447198 |title=By renaming migrants 'infiltrators,' Israel is forging a new reality |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>) refers to the act of [[Africa]]n nationals entering [[Israel]] in violation of Israeli law. This phenomenon began in the second half of the 2000s, when a large number of persons from Africa entered Israel, mainly through the [[Borders of Israel#Border with Egypt|fenced border between Israel and Egypt]]. According to the data of the [[Ministry of Interior (Israel)|Israeli Interior Ministry]], 26,635 people arrived illegally in this way by July 2010,<ref name="Knesset Crime data 3" >{{cite web |url=https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/m02625.pdf |script-title=he:נתונים על פשיעה של מסתננים ומבקשי מקלט וכנגד מסת ננים ומבקשי מקלט |language=he |trans-title=Data on crimes made by illegal immigrants and asylum seekers and of crimes made against illegal immigrants and asylum seekers|date=11 October 2010 |page=3 |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> and over 55,000 by January 2012.<ref>{{cite web |date=January 2012 |url=http://www.piba.gov.il/PublicationAndTender/ForeignWorkersStat/Documents/%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%9D%20%D7%A9%D7%A0%D7%AA%D7%99%202011.pdf |script-title=he:תוני זרים בישראל |language=he |trans-title=Israeli foreign data |publisher=Israeli authority of population and immigration |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> In an attempt to curb the influx,<ref name="telegraph.co.uk">Butcher, Tim. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/1504945/Sharon-presses-for-fence-across-Sinai.html Sharon presses for fence across Sinai], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', 7 December 2005.</ref> Israel constructed the [[Egypt–Israel barrier]], which was completed in December 2013.<ref name="algemeiner.com">[http://www.algemeiner.com/2013/12/04/245-mile-1-6-billion-shekel-security-fence-between-israel-and-sinai-completed Israel Completes 245 Mile, NIS 1.6 Billion Security Fence Along Sinai Border with Egypt] Algemeiner, DECEMBER 4, 2013 2:58 PM</ref>
As of January 2018, according to the Population and Immigration Authority (PIBA) there are 37,288 African migrants in Israel, not including children born to migrants in Israel.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/foreign_workers_in_israel_summary_2017/he/foreigners_in_Israel_data_2017_1.pdf|title=נתוני זרים בישראל|last=|first=|date=January 2018|website=Population and Immigration Authority|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=31 January 2018}}</ref>
African asylum seekers comprise 0.5% of Israel's population{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}. Most African migrants are generally regarded to be legitimate asylum seekers by various human rights organizations.<ref>{{cite web |date=8 October 2012 |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/10/28/israel-asylum-seekers-blocked-border |title=Israel: Asylum Seekers Blocked at Border |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=10 January 2012 |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/new-israeli-detention-law-violates-asylum-seekers-rights-2012-01-10 |title=Israel: New detention law violates rights of asylum-seekers |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
Many of the migrants seek an asylum status under the United Nations [[Convention relating to the Status of Refugees]]. However, many of them, mostly citizens of [[Eritrea]] and [[Sudan]], cannot be forcibly deported from Israel. Under international law, Eritrea citizens (who, since 2009, form the majority of the undocumented workers in Israel) cannot be deported due to the opinion of the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] (UNHCR) that Eritrea has a difficult internal situation and a forced recruitment and therefore the Eritrean immigrants are defined as a "temporary humanitarian protection group". Israeli authorities have stated that they could not deport Sudanese directly back to Sudan because Israel has no diplomatic ties to Sudan.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/report/2014/09/09/make-their-lives-miserable/israels-coercion-eritrean-and-sudanese-asylum-seekers|title="Make Their Lives Miserable"|last=|first=|date=9 September 2014|website=Human Rights Watch|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=21 January 2018}}</ref> Accordingly, the Israeli authorities grant temporary residence through "conditional release permits" which must be renewed every one to four months, depending on the discretion of the individual immigration official.<ref name=":1" /> Various authorities in Israel estimate that 80–90% of the undocumented workers live primarily in two centers: more than 60% in [[Tel Aviv]] and more than 20% [[Eilat]], with a few in [[Ashdod]], [[Jerusalem]] and [[Arad, Israel|Arad]].<ref name="Knesset Crime data 3" />
==Background== The [[UNHCR]] has declared [[Eritrea]] a country in humanitarian crisis. In the [[Darfur]] region in western Sudan, a [[genocide]] has been taking place since 2003. As a result, many of its residents became refugees and fled to [[Egypt]]. Added to those were refugees from [[southern Sudan]], where [[Second Sudanese Civil War|civil war]] took place between the predominantly [[Arab]] [[Muslim]] inhabitants of the north and the non-Arab, [[Christians]] and [[animists]] inhabitants of the south.
In 2009, in reports to UNHCR, Israel stated that 90% of the persons who arrived illegally from Sudan and Eritrea were genuine refugees.<ref>{{cite news |author=Sharon Livne |date=3 October 2010 |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/opinions/2.418/1.1223407 |script-title=he:פליטים, לא מסתננים |language=he |trans-title=Refugees, not infiltrators |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}} Letter to the editor.</ref>
==Status of the migrants == According to the government, the majority of the migrants are seeking economic opportunity. This is not the case among Israel's allies such as the United States, where the vast majority of Eritrean and Sudanese applicants are accepted as refugees. Once in Israel, African migrants have sought refugee status for fleeing forced, open-ended conscription in Eritrea or ethnic cleansing in the Darfur region of Sudan, but the government of Israel maintains that these areas merely have a poor human rights record, which does not automatically entitle one to asylum. To qualify, applicants must establish that they face the risk of personal harm or persecution if they return to their country. The [[Ministry of Interior (Israel)|Interior Ministry]] has failed to review the vast majority of asylum requests.<ref name="hope">{{cite news |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-african-migrants-in-israel-have-little-hope-2014jan07-story.html |title=African migrants in Israel have little hope |author=David Mac Dougall and Josef Federman |publisher=Associated Press |date=2014-01-07 |accessdate=2018-04-02}}</ref>
Most migrants request refugee status after arriving in Israel, in accordance with the United Nations's [[Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees]]. Israel does not review the status of the individual immigrants originating from Eritrea or Sudan, who constitute about 83% of the total people coming to Israel across the Egyptian border,<ref>{{cite web |date=April 2012 |url=http://www.piba.gov.il/PublicationAndTender/ForeignWorkersStat/Documents/אפריל%202012.pdf|script-title=he:נתוני זרים בישראל |language=he |trans-title=Israeli foreign data |publisher=Israel Population and Immigration Authority |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> and instead automatically grants them a [[Israeli policy for Sudanese and_Eritrean refugees | "temporary protection group"]] status. This status allows these people to have temporary residence right within Israel, which must be renew every 3 months; usually this also means that they would be eligible for a [[work permit]] in Israel. In the past Israel also granted an automatic "temporary protection group" status to all citizens of the [[Ivory Coast]] and [[South Sudan]], although since then the validity of this status has expired. Regarding the other asylum requests filed by citizens of other countries and examined individually, the Interior Ministry stated that only a fraction of them were actually eligible for refugee status.<ref>{{cite news| author=Zahava Galeon |date=12 November 2010 |url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/site/newsletter_opinion.php?id=4936&newsletter=12.11.2010 |script-title=he:מסיתים נגד פליטים |language=he |trans-title=Agitators against refugees |newspaper=[[Israel HaYom]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
==Development of illegal immigration from Africa to Israel== The Israeli government originally tolerated the new arrivals from Africa. It allowed their entry and many migrants found menial jobs in hotels and restaurants. But after their numbers swelled, concerns were raised.<ref name="hope"/> In the second half of the 2000s decade, there was a significant increase in the number of undocumented workers from Africa to Israel who crossed the Egyptian border. In 2006 about 1,000 undocumented workers were detained; in 2007 about 5,000 were detained; in 2008 about 8,700 were detained; and in 2009 about 5,000 were detained.<ref>{{cite web |date=26 May 2010 |script-title=he:הטיפול במסתננים מגבול מצרים |language=he |trans-title=Treatment infiltrators from the border with Egypt |url=https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/m02524.pdf |publisher=Knesset Research and Information Center |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> In the first half of 2010 the migration rate even further increased in the first seven months when over 8,000 undocumented workers were caught.<ref name="Knesset Crime data">{{cite web |url=https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/m02625.pdf |script-title=he:נתונים על פשיעה של מסתננים ומבקשי מקלט וכנגד מסת ננים ומבקשי מקלט |language=he |trans-title=Data on crimes made by illegal immigrants and asylum seekers and of crimes made against illegal immigrants and asylum seekers|date=11 October 2010 |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> The total number of undocumented workers is clearly greater than these figures, because many were not apprehended.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}} The early wave of undocumented workers came mainly from Sudan, while in 2009 the majority of the immigrants were from [[Eritrea]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
In early May 2010, it was estimated that 24,339 undocumented workers resided in Israel, of whom the number of Sudanese and Eritrean refugees who are not deportable under [[international law]] was 18,959: 5,649 Sudanese and 13,310 Eritreans. 16,766 of them received a special visa (ס 2א 5) granted to illegal immigrants who are non-deportable [[asylum seekers]]. Officially, the visa allows them only to stay in the country, but in practice the state also allows the refugees to work and avoids imposing fines on the Israeli employers who employ them. This special visa requires renewal every three months.<ref>{{cite web |date=8 June 2010 |script-title=he:קורבנות ניצול למטרות מין ועבדות בקרב המסתננים ומבקשי המקלט בישראל |language=he |trans-title=Victims of exploitation for sexual purposes and slavery among the infiltrators and asylum seekers in Israel |url=https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/doc.asp?doc=m02534&type=pdf |publisher=Knesset Research and Information Center |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> The Israeli immigration police patrols the neighborhoods of south [[Tel Aviv]] regularly and arrests asylum seekers who do not carry a valid visa; the punishment can be one to three months in prison. In his book "The Nightmare of the Exile" [[Adam Ahmed]] describes how such an arrest is performed.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Nightmare of the Exile|last=Ahmed|first=Adam|publisher=Xlibris|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=117–120}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}
141 immigrants, mostly from [[Ethiopia]], received [[refugee status]].
According to the IDF's Operations Division in 2008, most of the countries from where the illegal immigrants came are (in descending order): [[Eritrea]], [[Sudan]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Ivory Coast]] and [[Nigeria]]. Most of the illegal immigrants (85%) were men.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |date=December 2009 |url=http://web.hevra.haifa.ac.il/~ch-strategy/images/publications/darfur_refugees.pdf |script-title=he:פליטים או מהגרי עבודה ממדינות אפריקה |language=he |trans-title=Refugees or migrant workers from African states |publisher=Research Center, National Defense College and Chaikin Chair in Geostrategy, University of Haifa |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814142203/http://web.hevra.haifa.ac.il/~ch-strategy/images/publications/darfur_refugees.pdf |archivedate=14 August 2011 }}</ref>
===Immigration to Israel=== Most migrants initially arrive in [[Egypt]], and from there they often pay sums of up to two thousand dollars for [[Bedouin]] smugglers to transfer them to the border between Egypt and Israel. There have been cases of abuse against the female migrants committed by the Bedouin smugglers, including [[rape]], kidnapping for ransom, and murder. Another danger for the migrants includes the Egyptian army policy to shoot at them in order to prevent crossing the Egypt/Israel border.<ref>{{cite news |author=Liam Stack |date=13 November 2008|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2008/1113/p06s03-wome.html |title=Human Rights Watch faults Egypt's 'shoot-to-stop' policy |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Amir Bohbot |date=2 October 2011 |url=http://news.walla.co.il/?w=/0/1865224 |script-title=he:תופעה בגבול הדרומי: הצבא המצרי יורה במסתננים |language=he |trans-title=The southern border phenomenon: the Egyptian army shoots infiltrators |publisher=[[Walla!]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
To contain the illegal entry of persons, construction of the [[Egypt–Israel barrier]] commenced in 2012 and was completed in 2015. 9,570 citizens of various African countries entered Israel illegally in the first half of 2012, while only 34 did the same in the first six months of 2013, after construction of the main section of the barrier was completed.<ref>[http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/169521#.UeXqBUB15DQ New Data Shows 99% Drop in Illegal Entry], Arutz Sheva. 2 July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.netanyahu.org.il/en/news/573-99-6-drop-in-the-number-of-infiltrators-entering-israel-due-to-government-action 99.6% Drop in the Number of Infiltrators Entering Israel Due to Government Action] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930062343/http://netanyahu.org.il/en/news/573-99-6-drop-in-the-number-of-infiltrators-entering-israel-due-to-government-action |date=2013-09-30 }}, Israeli Prime Minister official website. 1 July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4402834,00.html Israel to trade arms for migrants with African countries], Ynetnews.com. 9 July 2013</ref> After the entire fence was completed, the number of migrant crossings had dropped to 16 in 2016.<ref>[http://m.jpost.com/Israel-News/Israel-completes-heightened-Egypt-border-fence-478840 ISRAEL COMPLETES HEIGHTENED EGYPT BORDER FENCE]</ref>
===Numbers and place of residence === As of April 2012, 59,858 illegal immigrants who were never imprisoned in detention facilities have illegally enter into Israel (in August 2010 the number of the imprisoned was 1,900).<ref>{{cite web |date=April 2012 |url=http://piba.gov.il/PublicationAndTender/ForeignWorkersStat/Documents/אפריל%202012.pdf |script-title=he:נתוני זרים בישראל |language=he |trans-title=Israel Foreign Data |publisher=Israel Population and Immigration Authority |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> Several thousands of them did not end up staying in the country.<ref>{{cite web |date=November 2011 |url=http://piba.gov.il/PublicationAndTender/ForeignWorkersStat/Documents/nov2011.pdf |script-title=he:נתוני זרים בישראל |language=he |trans-title=Israeli Foreign Data |publisher=Israel Population and Immigration Authority |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> The Israeli department of immigration does not keep continuous supervision over their place of residence but, according to estimates based on data from the Israeli police, the local authorities and the aid organizations, approximately 34,000 illegal immigrants originated from [[Eritrea]], about 15,000 originated from [[Sudan]] and 10,000 originated from other countries. The Israeli [[Administration of Border Crossings, Population and Immigration]] does not keep detailed documentation regarding their place of residence, but according to estimates from 2011, which are based on data from the Israeli police, the local authorities and the NGOs, circa 15,000–17,000 illegal immigrants lived in [[Tel Aviv]] (mainly in southern Tel Aviv, though the number also includes illegal immigrants living in [[Bat Yam]] and [[Bnei Brak]]) and 4,000–8,000 living in [[Eilat]]. While the estimates in [[Ashdod]] range from 1,500 to 2,000 illegal immigrants, in [[Jerusalem]] range from 1,000 to 8,000 illegal immigrants, and in [[Arad, Israel|Arad]] range from 400 to 600 illegal immigrants.<ref>{{cite web |date=25 May 2011 |url=https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/m02844.pdf |script-title=he:פשיעה של מסתננים ומבקשי מקלט וכנגד מסתננים ומבקשי מקלט |language=he |trans-title=Crime of infiltrators and asylum seekers and against infiltrators and asylum seekers |publisher=Knesset Research and Information Center |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> As of 2017, only 39,274 of those who entered the country remain.<ref name=":0" />
===Involvement in crime === In a discussion held by the police commissioner [[Dudi Cohen]] in December 2010, he stated that while there is a decline in cases of [[robberies]] in the general population, there is a dramatic increase in this type of crime among the illegal immigrants. According to the research department of the Israel Police and Israel's foreign immigrants' crime is characterized by predominantly sectoral internal crime, in which a gun is not reported, and illegal immigrants generally have no interest in complaining to the police.<ref name="Knesset Crime data" /> Due to an increase in criminal acts and the feeling of insecurity among the residents of southern Tel Aviv, the Israeli police established a new station near the New central bus station and the Shapira neighborhood.<ref>{{cite news |author=Avi Cohen |date=18 May 2012 |url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/site/newsletter_article.php?id=17206&hp=1&newsletter=18.05.2012 |script-title=he:פחד ברחובות |language=he |trans-title=Fear in the streets |newspaper=[[Israel HaYom]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> The station includes approximately 100 police officers and is expected to accommodate about 150 police officers. According to the data of the Israeli Police, which was presented to the Knesset in March 2012, from 2007 there was a steady increase in the involvement in crime of the illegal immigrants, both due to the significant increase in their numbers and for various other reasons. In 2011, 1,200 [[criminal case]]s were opened against illegal immigrants from Africa, half of them in the Tel Aviv district. This is an increase of 54% in comparison to the previous year.<ref>{{cite news |author=Omri Efraim |date=19 March 2012 |script-title=he:המשטרה: עלייה של 23% בפשיעת הזרים |language=he |trans-title=Police: up 23% of crime is foreign |publisher=[[Ynet]] }} http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/1,7340,L-4204802,00.html</ref>
Massive protests supporting the illegal immigrants and promoting their remaining in Israel have taken place<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/amphtml/world/africa/thousands-of-africans-protest-israeli-deportation-plan/2018/03/24/cda24fea-2f91-11e8-8dc9-3b51e028b845_story.html|title=Thousands of Africans protest Israeli deportation plan|website=www.washingtonpost.com|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5130004,00.html|title=20,000 asylum seekers, supporters, protest in Tel Aviv|date=2018-02-25|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> simultaneous with other Israelis calling for their deportation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.mida.org.il/2017/03/22/south-tel-aviv-overtaken-illegal-immigrants-media-silent/|title=South Tel Aviv Being Overtaken by Illegal Immigrants, Media is Silent|date=2017-03-22|work=Mida|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5127607,00.html|title=Masses expected to attend Tel Aviv migrant solidarity rally|date=2018-02-23|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> Crime is a major factor for residents who call for the government to repatriate the migrants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4230650,00.html|title=3 Africans suspected of raping 15-year-old girl|date=2012-05-17|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> Examples include the murder of 68-year-old Esther Galili<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://m.maariv.co.il/news/law/Article-588893|title=תושבת דרום תל אביב מאשימה את המשטרה: "היה אפשר למנוע את רצח אמי"|access-date=2018-03-24|language=he-IL}}</ref> who was beaten to death near her South Tel Aviv home in 2010 by a drunken Sudanese migrant. Her daughter Corine Galili is now an activist with the Residents of Southern Tel Aviv council.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/155947|title=‘Murders by Illegals go Unreported’|website=Israel National News|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> Another example includes the rape of 83-year-old Ester Nahman by a 17-year-old Eritrean migrant in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://m.jpost.com/National-News/Charge-Eritrean-raped-and-beat-83-yr-old-for-hours|title=Charge: Eritrean raped and beat 83-yr-old for hours|work=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/170004|title=Eritrean Immigrant Held on Rape, Robbery of Disabled TA Woman|website=Israel National News|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> There has also been a concern of crimes committed by migrants against migrants including rape and murder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/african-migrant-murdered-in-south-tel-aviv/amp/|title=African migrant murdered in south Tel Aviv {{!}} The Times of Israel|website=www.timesofisrael.com|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/sudanese-woman-found-dead-in-south-tel-aviv/|title=Sudanese minor found dead in south Tel Aviv|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> According to David Filo, the police commander in charge of the district that includes south Tel Aviv, the local police station went from only four or five officers before the wave of immigrants, to more than 200 as of 2017 on duty around the clock due to the increase in crime. He stated that statistics indicate most of the crimes reported are between immigrants and include theft, drug sales and domestic violence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.makorrishon.co.il/nrg/online/1/ART2/896/830.html|title=מקור ראשון, ''אם מישהו מפחד לצאת, יהיה כוח שייגש אליו''|work=NRG|access-date=2018-03-24|language=he}}</ref>
Israeli police reported experiencing difficulties dealing with criminal cases involving illegal immigrants originating from Africa, since the police do not possess interpreters who are capable of speaking the [[Tigrinya language]] spoken in [[Eritrea]]. In addition, the Israeli legal system also has reported a serious difficulty in conducting proper criminal procedures involving suspects who speak only the [[Tigrinya language]].<ref>{{cite news |date=13 March 2012 |url=http://www.news1.co.il/uploadFiles/433315455913544.doc |script-title=he:מדינת ישראל נגד ביינה סמרהרט |language=he |trans-title=State of Israel v. Byena Smarhart |publisher=[[Supreme Court of Israel]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
In her ruling on the [[Holot]] "open detention facility", Israeli Supreme Court justice Edna Arbel stated that there is disagreement regarding the factual situation, whereas there are studies that show that the level of crime committed by infiltrators is lower than that in society in general. She however emphasized that the distressful feeling of the residents of South Tel Aviv that the level of security in their neighborhoods has decreased considerably, should not be underestimated.<ref>{{cite web |date=16 September 2013 |last1=Arbel|first1=Edna|title=Adam v. The Knesset|url=http://elyon1.court.gov.il/files_eng/12/460/071/b24/12071460.b24.pdf |publisher=[[Supreme Court of Israel]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
==Development of the state's treatment of African asylum seekers== [[File:Holot detention center.jpg|thumb|The entrance to Holot immigration detention center, Negev desert, Israel.]] In 2010 Israel began building a [[Israel–Egypt barrier|barrier]] along sections of its border with Egypt to curb the influx of [[refugees]] from African countries. Construction was completed in January 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Israel completes bulk of Egypt border fence |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/02/us-israel-egypt-fence-idUSBRE9010EI20130102 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=2 January 2013 |accessdate=2 January 2013}}</ref> 230 km of fence have been built.<ref>{{cite news |author=Herb Keinon |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/PM-tours-South-heralds-completion-of-border-fence |title=PM tours South, heralds completion of border fence |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=2 January 2013 |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> While 9,570 citizens of various African countries entered Israel illegally in the first half of 2012, only 34 did the same in the first six months of 2013, after construction of the barrier was completed. It represents a decrease of over 99%.<ref>{{cite news |author=Maayana Miskin |date=2 July 2013 |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/169521 |title=New Data Shows 99% Drop in Illegal Entry |publisher=[[Arutz Sheva]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.netanyahu.org.il/en/news/573-99-6-drop-in-the-number-of-infiltrators-entering-israel-due-to-government-action |title=99.6% Drop in the Number of Infiltrators Entering Israel Due to Government Action |publisher=Benjamin Netanyahu Official Website |date=1 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930062343/http://netanyahu.org.il/en/news/573-99-6-drop-in-the-number-of-infiltrators-entering-israel-due-to-government-action |archivedate=30 September 2013 }}</ref>
Israel also began deporting thousands of illegal immigrants who were residing in the country.<ref>{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |date=3 June 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/03/israel-plan-migrants-deport-east-africa |title=Israel planning to deport African migrants to 'east African country' |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/middleeast/la-fg-israel-refugees-20130716,0,3081312.story |title=Israel begins deporting Eritrean refugees to troubled African homeland |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=15 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130717050104/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/middleeast/la-fg-israel-refugees-20130716%2C0%2C3081312.story |archivedate=17 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2013 Israel began to deport illegal immigrants to Uganda, reportedly in exchange for weapons and military training. In November 2017 Israel announced its intent to deport thousands of illegal immigrants by March 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/israel-tells-african-migrants-asylum-seekers-to-leave-or-go-to-jail_us_5a4fc2c6e4b003133ec79e39|title=Israel Tells African Migrants, Asylum-Seekers To Leave Or Go To Jail|last=Cook|first=Jesselyn|date=2018-01-05|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-01-14|language=English}}</ref> African migrants are told to choose between returning to their home countries or being sent to third countries, that are rumored to be Rwanda and Uganda.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/01/05/world/africa/ap-af-africa-israel-migrants.html|title=Rwanda, Uganda Deny Deal With Israel to Take Africa Migrants|last=Press|first=The Associated|date=2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-14|language=English|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The Israeli Knesset announced that illegal immigrants who do not leave by March 2018 will be jailed until they leave Israel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://972mag.com/the-new-choice-for-asylum-seekers-deportation-or-prison/131534/|title=The new ‘choice’ for asylum seekers: Deportation or prison {{!}} +972 Magazine|website=972mag.com|language=English|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
In 2012, the Israeli Knesset passed an "anti-infiltration law." Many Africans who entered after the bill's passage or those whose visas have expired have been to the or the neighboring [[Saharonim prison]]. Advocates like MK [[Michal Rozin]] visited Saharonim and said that migrants received adequate food and medical care and were not mistreated, but said that sending migrants there was inhumane. However, conditions for many refugees elsewhere in the region are worse, and Israeli officials maintained that conditions there were adequate.<ref name="prison">{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/israeli-detention-center-africans-prison |title=Israeli: Detention center for Africans a 'prison' |author=Diaa Hadid |publisher=Associated Press |date=2013-07-14 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref> After the [[Supreme Court of Israel]] declared that the long-term custody of migrants in Sahronim was unconstitutional, the government opened [[Holot]], an open detention center, in December 2013. The 1,800 residents at [[Holot]] are allowed to leave but are required to sign in once a day and return for an evening curfew.<ref name="hope"/><ref name="seder">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/african-migrants-in-israel-hold-passover-seder/ |title=African migrants in Israel hold Passover seder |author=Tia Goldenberg |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2014-04-11 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref> Israeli courts temporarily cancelled the summonses of African migrants to the Holot facility, and froze others until appeals can be heard against them. Judges also criticized the summons process, saying there exist fundamental problems, including the failure to examine individual circumstances and the lack of hearings for illegal immigrants. The government stated that hearings were not necessary because ordering the migrants to travel to Holot does not violate their human rights.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/.premium-1.575211 |title=Judges nix summonses of illegal immigrants, slam Israel's detention policy |author=Ilan Lior |publisher=''Haaretz'' |date=2014-02-20 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref>
On 22 September 2014, the High Court struck down the anti-infiltration law (under which the [[Holot]] facility operated) and ordered the state to close [[Holot]] within 90 days.<ref name=Holot1>{{cite news | author = Ilan Lior | title = High Court orders closure of detention facility for African asylum seekers | newspaper = [[Haaretz]] | date = 22 September 2014 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/.premium-1.617143}}</ref> The court addressed two measures: (1) whether to limit the detention of migrants, and (2) whether to close Holot. On both measures, the court sided with the petitioners (the [[Association for Civil Rights in Israel]], the Hotline for Refugees and Migrants, ASSAF, [[Kav LaOved]], [[Physicians for Human Rights–Israel]], and [[Amnesty International]]–Israel).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/in-dramatic-ruling-supreme-court-rejects-israels-policies-on-illegal-migrants/ |title=In dramatic ruling, High Court rejects Israel’s policies on illegal migrants |author=Marissa Newman |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2014-09-22}}</ref> The ruling said that conditions at the facility were an "unbearable violation of [their] basic rights, first and foremost the right to freedom and the right to dignity".<ref name=Holot1/> Illegal migrants can no longer be detained for up to a year without trial, however detention continues within legal boundaries.<ref name="new law">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-ministers-mull-new-migrant-law/ |title=Netanyahu, ministers mull new migrant law |publisher=AFP |date=2014-10-07}}</ref> The detentions in Holot have continued, with illegal immigrants being detained for a year and then being prevented from living in Tel Aviv and Eilat upon their release.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/26/middleeast/israel-migrant-release/index.html|title=Israel frees 1,200 migrants, bans them from Tel Aviv - CNN|last=CNN|first=[[Oren Liebermann]]|work=CNN|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> In November 2017, the Israeli government announced that it would be closing the Holot Detention Center within four months.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5044929,00.html|title=Government approves closure of Holot facility within 4 months|date=2017-11-19|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
A law passed in 2017 required that employers impose a 20 per cent deduction on the [[wages]] of workers who entered the country illegally from [[Egypt]]. The deducted money is deposited in a fund along with an employer paid [[Taxation in Israel|tax]] of 16 per cent. This money is accessible to workers only when they leave Israel.<ref>{{Cite web| title = African migrant families battle hunger in Israel| work = Middle East Monitor| accessdate = 2018-11-08| date = 2018-11-08| url = https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20181108-african-migrant-families-battle-hunger-in-israel/}}</ref>
In April 2018, Israel reached an agreement with the [[United Nations]] to expel around 16,000 African migrants to Western countries in exchange for granting temporary residency in Israel to the same number.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Israel-announces-it-reached-deal-with-UN-on-deportation-of-asylum-seekers-547703|title=Israel reaches deal with U.N. to resettle asylum seekers in Western states|work=Jerusalem Post|date=2018-04-02}}</ref> Shortly after, however, the deal was cancelled by the Israeli government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Netanyahu-completes-about-face-on-migrants-says-UNHRC-deal-is-cancelled-547777|title=Netanyahu completes about-face on migrants, says UNHCR deal is cancelled|work=Jerusalem Post|date=2018-04-03}}</ref>
==Aid organizations== Israel has a number of organizations focused on helping the asylum seekers in Israel (mainly by legal aid) including the Hotline for Refugees and Migrants, ASSAF, [[Physicians for Human Rights-Israel]], [[African Refugees Development Center]] and [[Association for Civil Rights in Israel]]. The secular Jewish organization [[BINA Center for Jewish Identity and Hebrew Culture|Bina]], located in south Tel Aviv, has helped asylum seekers as well as Israeli citizens understand refugee rights, and has undertaken advocacy and educational activities including frequent trips for Israelis to visit the Holot Detention Center. Most of these organization are funded by the [[New Israel Fund]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Akiva Bigman |date=1 January 2014 |url=http://mida.org.il/2014/01/01/%D7%90%D7%A1%D7%98%D7%A8%D7%98%D7%92%D7%99%D7%99%D7%AA-%D7%94%D7%93%D7%A2%D7%95%D7%95%D7%94-%D7%A9%D7%9C-%D7%94%D7%A7%D7%A8%D7%9F-%D7%94%D7%97%D7%93%D7%A9%D7%94-%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%A9%D7%A8%D7%90/ |script-title=he:אסטרטגיית ה'דעווה' של הקרן החדשה לישראל |language=he |trans-title=The strategy 'Dawa' of the New Israel Fund |publisher=MIDA |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> Relief organizations have been involved in discussions held in Knesset committees on this issue and have submitted a petition against the measures the state has taken to put a halt to the phenomenon of immigration.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
==Reactions in Israel to asylum seekers and illegal immigration== The situation underscores the tension between two strong feelings in Israel. Israel was founded in the wake of the Holocaust and has provided refuge to Jews fleeing oppression around the world. On one hand, many Israelis feel Israel has a special responsibility to assist refugees in such dire conditions. On the other hand, many Israelis fear the continued migration of illegal immigrants and refugees would threaten the Jewish majority.<ref name="hope"/><ref name="seder"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sabar|first=Galia|last2=Tsurkov|first2=Elizabeth|date=May 2015|title=Israel's Policies towards Asylum-Seekers:2012-2014|url=|journal=Instituto Affari Internazionali|volume=20|pages=2–18|isbn=978-88-98650-44-6|via=}}</ref>
Israeli reaction to African migrants has been mixed, with groups protesting on both sides. Human Rights advocates have been outspoken about their concerns about the treatment of asylum seekers and migrants. In 2010, Israelis protested the construction of the [https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.694423 Holot detention facility], which was built to detain illegal immigrants, stating that its construction goes against Human Rights values. At the same time, residents of South Tel Aviv demonstrated against the presence of foreigners living in their communities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/thousands-in-tel-aviv-protest-plan-for-refugee-detention-facility-1.332737|title=Thousands in Tel Aviv Protest Plan for Refugee Detention Facility|last=Lior|first=Ilan|date=24 December 2010|work=Haaretz|access-date=14 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In 2012, nearly 1,000 Israelis, mostly from neighborhoods in South Tel Aviv staged a protest against illegal immigrants, joined by Member of [[Knesset]], [[Miri Regev]], they asked the government for deportation and expulsion of migrants from Africa. MK [[Miri Regev]] stated "the Sudanese were a cancer in our body." This protest led to destruction of property and businesses owned by Sudanese and Eritrean people as well as violence against said people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/06/10/israel-amend-anti-infiltration-law|title=Israel: Amend ‘Anti-Infiltration’ Law|last=|first=|date=10 June 2012|website=Human Rights Watch|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/demonstrators-attack-african-migrants-in-south-tel-aviv-1.432262|title=Demonstrators Attack African Migrants in South Tel Aviv|last=Lior|first=Ilan|date=24 May 2012|work=Haaretz|access-date=14 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In 2015, an immigrant from Eritrea, Habtom Zarhum, was beaten to death by a mob after being misidentified as an assailant in a [[Beersheva bus station shooting|terrorist attack at the Beersheva bus station]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.681069|title=Two Dead, 11 Wounded in Shooting Attack in Southern Israel|last=Ben Zikri|first=Almog|date=19 October 2015|website=Haaretz|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 January 2018}}</ref>
In the face of discrimination against asylum seekers, who are often believed to be migrant workers or illegal immigrants, many Israelis have continued to show their support over the years for the community. Refugee [[Passover Seder|Seders]] have been held each year during the Jewish holiday of [[Passover]], most recently taking place at Holot detention facility to show solidarity and support to the men living in detention.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Activists-hold-Seder-for-African-asylum-seekers-at-Holot-facility-451436|title=CTIVISTS HOLD SEDER FOR AFRICAN ASYLUM-SEEKERS AT HOLOT FACILITY|last=Sharon|first=Jeremy|date=17 April 2016|work=Jerusalem Post|access-date=14 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Support for refugees and immigrants to Israel is also demonstrated through the work of numerous non-profit organizations, including [http://www.kavlaoved.org.il/en/ Kav LaOved (Worker's Hotline]), [https://www.ardc-israel.org/ ARDC], [http://assaf.org.il/en/node/2 ASSAF]. In late 2017, early 2018, prominent North American Jewish organizations joined with Israeli NGO’s to decry Israel’s recent decisions to close Holot and deport asylum seekers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/North-American-Jewish-leaders-Please-dont-deport-Africans-533195|title=NORTH AMERICAN JEWISH LEADERS: PLEASE DON’T DEPORT AFRICANS|last=Eisenbud|first=Daniel|date=9 January 2018|work=Jerusalem Post|access-date=14 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
The Israeli demographer [[Arnon Soffer]] has expressed his opposition to the African illegal immigration phenomenon for several reasons. He claims that from a security perspective, they may serve as "[[informant]]" or as "operatives of hostile states or [[terrorist organization]]s". Socially, he claims that they are contributing to the [[:wikt:congestion|congestion]] in the cities and to the rise in [[crime]]. From the demographic perspective, he perceives the asylum seekers and illegal immigrants to be a [[Demographic threat#Israel|demographic threat]] to the [[Israeli Jews|Jewish majority]]. According to Sofer, failing to stop the illegal immigration waves at an early stage will only lead to much larger waves of illegal immigration in the future.<ref name="autogenerated1" />
The Israeli economic commentator [[Nehemiah Shtrasler]] estimated that the illegal immigrants take the places of weaker manual workers, causing loss of jobs and a reduction in the wages. He also claimed that they burden the health care, welfare and education systems. "We would never be able to raise the standard of living of the needy and reduce the gaps, if we keep on absorbing more and more destitute people."<ref>{{cite news |date=24 September 2010 |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/opinions/1.1222412 |script-title=he:נחמיה שטרסלר | 40 מסתננים ליום |language=he |trans-title=Nehemiah Shtrasler | 4- Infiltrators a day |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
The Israeli [[Member of the Knesset|MK]] [[Ya'akov Katz (politician born 1951)|Ya'akov Katz (Katzele)]], who headed the government committee aimed at creating a solution to what they perceive to be an issue of illegal asylum seekers migrating to Israel, warned from immigration through the Israel–Egypt border and stated that if the current immigration rate to Israel would continue, within a few years there would be hundreds of thousands of illegal workers in Israel and that this would constitute a "demographic threat" to Israel, in addition to the other issues this situation would lead to, such as an "increase in crime and poverty in the areas in which the immigrants concentrate". One of Katz's proposals was to establish a city near the Egyptian border, where the immigrants would be gathered before being deported from the country.<ref>{{cite news |author=Roni Sofer |date=28 December 2010 |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4005787,00.html |script-title=he:ח"כ כ"ץ: כדור בראש לבדואים שעוזרים למסתננים |language=he |trans-title=MK Katz: ball at the top of the Bedouins who help the infiltrators |publisher=[[Ynet]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
In December 2011, Mayor of Tel Aviv [[Ron Huldai]] addressed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and demanded that the government would take "immediate emergency actions" against the immigrants. Huldai stated "Israel cannot continue to ignore the growing wave of immigrants, which at this point it is clear to everyone that they infiltrate to Israel as migrant workers and that they are not in an existential threat." Huldai called to "protect Israel's borders against infiltration" and also to allocate the necessary resources for the immigrants who already entered the country "and caused severe distress to the residents of the neighborhoods who were forced to deal with this influx".<ref>{{cite news |author=Gilad Morag |date=4 December 2011 |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4156696,00.html |script-title=he:חולדאי לנתניהו: תושבים מופקרים מול המסתננים |language=he |trans-title=Huldai to Netanyahu: Residents abandoned in front of the infiltrators |publisher=[[Ynet]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
In Israeli cities that have high rates of African illegal immigrants, a resistance has emerged among the local population against this phenomenon. In mid-2010, a demonstration was held in Eilat against the non-action of the Israeli government, the residents claimed that they are now afraid to walk outside at certain neighborhoods at night.<ref>{{cite news |author=Ahuva Mamus |date=11 July 2010 |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3918106,00.html |script-title=he:הפליטים רוצים להישאר באילת: "לא כולם סודנים" |language=he |trans-title=Refugees want to stay in Eilat, "not all Sudanese" |publisher=[[Ynet]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> In the Shapira and Kiryat Shalom neighborhoods in the southern part of Tel Aviv a number of real estate agents have stated that they intend not to rent apartments in these neighborhoods to the illegal immigrants.<ref>{{cite news |author=Noah Koshrik |date=2 August 2010 |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/news/education/1.1214829 |script-title=he:מתווכים בדרום ת"א: לא נשכיר דירות לשב"חים |language=he |trans-title=Realtors in south Tel Aviv: illegal aliens will not rent apartments |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
On 23 May 2012 a demonstration was held in the [[Hatikva Quarter]], in which more than a thousand Israeli protesters protested against the way the Israeli government has been handling the influx of immigrants so far. During the demonstration the MKs [[Miri Regev]], [[Danny Danon]], [[Ronit Tirosh]] and [[Michael Ben-Ari]] held speeches. Later on the protest turned violent, as the participants began attacking passersby people, shattered panes of stores belonging to owners of African descent, burned garbage cans and clashed with the police forces.<ref>{{cite news |author=Neri Brenner |author2=Boaz Feiler |date=23 May 2012 |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4233445,00.html |script-title=he:מהומה ועצורים בהפגנה בדרום ת"א: זרים הותקפו |language=he |trans-title=Pandemonium and arrests at the demonstration in south Tel Aviv: Foreigners attacked |publisher=[[Ynet]] |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> [[President of Israel|President]] [[Shimon Peres]] issued a condemnation of the violent words and actions against the African migrant workers, calling on [[Israelis]] to refrain from racism and incitement, saying: "Hatred of foreigners contradicts the fundamental principles of [[Judaism]]. I am well aware of the difficulties faced by the residents of south Tel Aviv [and other similar areas], but violence is not the solution."<ref name=no-violence>{{cite news |author=Yoni Hirsch |author2=Shlomo Cesana |author3=Yori Yalon |author4=Itsik Saban |author5=Gideon Allon |author6=Yael Branovsky |title='No place for violence against African migrants and refugees' |url=http://www.israelhayom.com/site/newsletter_article.php?id=4472 |accessdate=11 January 2014 |newspaper=[[Israel HaYom]] |date=25 May 2012}}</ref>
In a Channel 2 interview in November 2013, Tel Aviv Mayor Ron Huldai scoffed at government policy toward the migrants, saying, "Can 50,000 people be a demographic threat? That's a mockery. ... The truth is they will remain here. They are human beings and I must take care of them."<ref name="future">{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/features/2013/12/22/Africans-face-uncertain-Israeli-future-after-perilous-migration.html|title=Africans face uncertain Israeli future after perilous migration|date=2013-12-22|accessdate=2014-05-08|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|agency=Reuters}}</ref>
On the other hand, demonstrations, rallies and other event supporting the refugees have also been held regularly.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100001052021479&sk=wall |title=Ann Tifa Rave |publisher=Facebook |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=11 March 2009 |url=http://wn.com/darfur_muslim_refugees_demonstrating_in_israel_to_support_icc |title=Muslim Refugees Demonstrating In Israel To Support Icc |publisher=World News Inc. |accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/7708463-african-refugees-protest-in-israel |title=African Refugees Protest in Israel protests |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110729054437/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/7708463-african-refugees-protest-in-israel |archivedate=29 July 2011 }}</ref> On 28 December 2013 thousands have protested in [[Tel Aviv]] against detention of asylum seekers from Sudan and Eritrea. The protesters, marched from [[Levinsky Park]] in South Tel Aviv to city center, decrying the detention without trial of African refugees in the [[Saharonim]] and [[Holot]] detention facilities. Migrants have reportedly said to fear for their life should they return to their home countries.<ref>Itay Blumenthal, [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4470485,00.html TA: Thousands protest against detention of asylum seekers], ''YNetNews'', 28 December 2013, Retrieved 29 December 2013</ref>
On 15 January 2014, the Knesset Committee on Foreign Workers met to discuss the Immigration and Border Authority policy toward illegal immigrants and its impact on the business sector. African migrants were present and participated in the Knesset meeting. They were supported by MK [[Michal Rozin]] of [[Meretz]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/african-migrants-take-part-in-knesset-meeting/ |title=Week after ban, African migrants take part in Knesset meeting |author=Lazar Berman |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2014-01-15 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref>
In April 2014, activists organized a [[Passover seder]] with asylum seekers at the Holot facility to recall the [[Passover]] story and call attention to the plight of the migrants. Similar seders were held in support of the migrants in Tel Aviv and Washington.<ref name="seder"/> Similar events took place in 2015 and 2016, the seder in 2016 also celebrated in Holot detention center was dedicated to raise awareness to the shortage and poor quality of food in Holot<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/iw/originals/2016/04/holot-refugees-detention-freedom-passover-seder-eritrea.html#|title=מבקשי המקלט שכלואים ב״חולות״ מחכים לחג החירות שלהם|last=פולס|first=ישראל|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Reactions among American Jews == Reactions among American Jews span the spectrum of Israeli politics on this issue and are evolving into a robust debate. The Maryland-based refugee rights organization HIAS, whose Israeli branch has been actively assisting African asylum seekers,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hias.org/hias-israel|title=HIAS in Israel|work=HIAS|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> has vocally opposed the Israeli government’s policy toward the asylum seekers and has called on Israel to evaluate their refugee status claims in accordance with international law.<ref name="HIAS">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hias.org/hias-calls-protection-refugees-and-asylum-seekers-israel|title=HIAS Calls for Protection of Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Israel|work=HIAS|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> The Los Angeles-based organization StandWithUs, whose mission is "supporting Israel around the world -- through education and fighting anti-Semitism",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.standwithus.com/aboutus/|title=StandWithUs About Us|last=HagaiZamir.com|website=www.standwithus.com|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> states that "most of the migrants came to Israel seeking work opportunities, not as refugees escaping war"; as StandWithUs elaborates, "unlike refugees who are fleeing war or persecution, economic migrants leave their countries in search of better work opportunities."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.swuconnect.com/insys/npoflow.v.2/_assets/pdfs/fact_sheets/African%20Migrants%20in%20Israel%20factsheet.pdf|title=African Migrants in Israel - Factsheet|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, globally, national authorities have found asylum seekers from Eritrea deserving of refugee status in 84% of applications, and have granted refugee status to Sudanese asylum seekers 56% of the time, whereas Israel has only granted 1% of asylum petitions from these asylum seekers.<ref name="HIAS"/> Mandatory lifetime conscription is among the human-rights abuses in Eritrea from which they may be fleeing.<ref name="truah.org">{{Cite web|url=http://www.truah.org/campaign/asylum-seekers-in-israel/|title=Asylum Seekers in Israel {{!}} T'ruah|website=www.truah.org|language=English|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> The Rabbinical Assembly, the clergy organization of Conservative Judaism, passed a resolution in 2016 stating that "Israel’s Ministry of the Interior has been very reluctant to grant refugee status to bona fide asylum seekers" and calling on Israel to do so.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rabbinicalassembly.org/story/resolution-african-asylum-seekers-israel|title=Resolution on African Asylum Seekers in Israel {{!}} The Rabbinical Assembly|website=www.rabbinicalassembly.org|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> The rabbinic human-rights organization T’ruah, based in New York, has made it a priority to encourage Israel to evaluate all asylum seekers’ claims fairly.<ref name="truah.org"/>

A '''Spanish Jamaican''' is a Jamaican citizen of [[Spanish people|Spanish]] origin or descent.
==Notable people==
* [[Frank Silvera]], Jamaican American actor and director * [[Ken Khouri]], Jamaican Record Producer * [[Lady Colin Campbell]], Jamaican radio host, author, and socialite
==Spanish Colonization of Santiago (Jamaica)== The Spaniards first settled on that part of the northern coast of Jamaica which is now known as the parish of [[Saint Ann Parish|St. Ann]]. There they built a town called Sevilla Nueva, or New Seville. Afterwards they moved to the southern part of the island and built the town of [[St. Jago de la Vega]], which is still called [[Spanish Town]]. The island was given to the Columbus family as a personal estate in 1540, but they did nothing to develop it. The Spanish colony in Jamaica was never a very large or a very flourishing one.
==Spanish cities and towns in Jamaica== The reminders of this historical period are the names of places all over the island, Such as [[Ocho Rios]], [[Rio Bueno, Jamaica|Rio Bueno]], [[Santa Cruz, Jamaica|Santa Cruz]], [[Rio Cobre]], [[Port Antonio]] and most importantly Spanish Town, formerly known as St. Jago de la Vega, the capital under the Spanish.<ref>[http://www.discoverjamaica.com/gleaner/discover/geography/history1.htm JAMAICAN HISTORY I <!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130805083846/http://www.discoverjamaica.com/gleaner/discover/geography/history1.htm |date=2013-08-05 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Colony of Santiago (Jamaica)]]
